title: U.S. likely added 173,000 jobs in August, but watch out for an end-of-summer surprise
text:
Getty Images People walk along a shopping street in lower Manhattan. The U.S. economy is still creating lots of new jobs more than a decade after the last recession.

The U.S. is not creating new jobs as fast as it was last year, but it’s still putting enough new hires to work to keep growth afloat even as the economy enters choppier waters.

Here’s what to watch in the August employment report due Friday morning.

Steady hiring ...

Economists polled by MarketWatch predict the U.S. added 173,000 jobs last month, marking a slight increase from July.

So far this year the U.S. has produced an average of 165,000 new jobs a month, down from a 223,000 pace in 2018. A slowing economy hurt by the trade war with China is part of the reason, but hiring was bound to slow after the creation of nearly 22 million jobs since 2010.

The good news? The U.S. only has to create about 100,000 new jobs a month — or even less — to soak up all the new people entering the labor force and keep the unemployment rate near a 50-year low.

Read: ADP says 195,000 private-sector jobs added in August

... with one big caveat

Don’t be surprised if job gains are disappointing, however. Economists at NatWest Markets point out that the government’s initial estimate of new jobs created in August has fallen well short of Wall Street’s forecast in seven of the past 10 years.

The average gap: 43,000.

With so many people on vacation in August, the number of respondents to the government’s monthly questionnaire is often the lowest of the year. As more responses are returned, the government usually ends up revising job growth higher. That’s happened in eight of the past 10 years.

Read: Service-oriented firms grow faster in August, cushion economy from China trade war



Where the jobs are

Manufacturers have sharply cut back on hiring. Energy companies, too. The retail industry, meanwhile, continues to shed jobs amid an onslaught by online competitors.

Most of the new jobs being created are in hotels, restaurants, hospitals and white-collar fields such as tech. Employment in construction also appears to be on the rebound as falling mortgage rates draw in more prospective home buyers.

Ultra-low unemployment

The jobless rate has hovered between 3.6% and 3.8% in the past six months and that’s unlikely to change. Economists predict unemployment will stick to 3.7%.

A broader measure of unemployment known as U6 — often referred to as the real unemployment rate — fell to 7.1% in July to mark the lowest level since 2001.



Rising wages

Just a year ago the Federal Reserve started to worry about rising wages as it moved to lift U.S. interest rates. And now? The central bank seems to have no worries at all even though wage growth remains fairly strong. The Fed is expected to cut rates again later this month.

Average hourly earnings are expected to increase 0.3% in August, leaving the increase over the past year at 3.2%. Wages typically rise 3% to 4% a year when the economy is peaking.

Keep an eye on the average number of hours employees work each week. It fell to a nearly two-year low of 34.3 hours in July. If it falls again it would surely raise alarms.
